Trump administration torn between grief and retaliation after Charlie Kirk's assassination
subhead: The American president mourned the young MAGA leader killed on Wednesday in Utah as if he were a member of his own family. For Trump's supporters, the crime justifies the 'war' being waged against the 'radical left' and 'woke ideology.'

title: In Germany, social welfare is 'no longer sustainable'
subhead: At the end of August, Chancellor Friedrich Merz called for an 'autumn of reform,' paving the way for a broad debate across the country to save Germany's welfare state.

title: Electric cars: European carmakers lobby Brussels to extend combustion engine deadline
subhead: Europe's automotive industry, facing a crisis, is ramping up pressure on the European Union. On Friday, September 12, carmakers and automotive suppliers will make their case to Ursula von der Leyen, urging the president of the European Commission to ease the planned 2035 ban on new combustion engine vehicle sales.
byline: By Sophie Fay and Virginie Malingre (Brussels, Europe bureau)

title: Living, eating and sleeping on the road: The grueling life of China's 38 million truck drivers
subhead: Nearly 70% of goods are transported across the country by truck, an essential part of the economy. But China's slowdown in growth coincides with a deterioration in working conditions and the rise of digital platforms.

From a Thai holiday to a Turkish prison: How two women were trapped by drug traffickers
subhead: The two 20-year-old women from the Paris region enjoyed an all-expenses-paid holiday in Thailand, then given suitcases packed with cannabis before their flight home. Their lawyers argued it was a case of 'great naivety.'

title: Hyundai and LG's giant US plant in shock after massive immigration raid
subhead: The South Korean companies' metaplant in Georgia was the target of a vast federal immigration raid on September 4, during which 475 people were detained.

title: France's 'Block Everything' protests converge around ousting Macron
subhead: Although France did not come to a standstill or grind to a halt on Wednesday, numerous protests took place throughout the day across the country with large gatherings in certain cities – with headcounts between 197,000 and 250,000 people – amid the firm presence of law enforcement.
